awd_titl_txt: Atomistic Modeling of the Generation of Metastable Nanoparticles and Surface Structures in Pulsed Laser Ablation in Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
The generation of chemically clean and environmentally friendly nanoparticles through pulsed laser ablation in liquids has a number of advantages over conventional chemical synthesis methods and has evolved into a thriving research field attracting laboratory and industrial applications. This award supports fundamental research aimed at revealing, through advanced computer modeling and theoretical analysis, the mechanisms and kinetics of structural and phase transformations occurring in pulsed laser ablation in liquids. The emerging physical understanding of these phenomena will facilitate the development of new laser processing techniques capable of controlled generation of nanoparticles and surface structures with properties fine-tuned for biomedical, optical, photovoltaic, and sensing applications.  This research will provide educational and training opportunities through the involvement of the participating students in high-performance parallel computing, and through broadening participation of U.S. university students in the Venice International School on Lasers in Materials Science.

While, experimentally, the presence of the liquid environment has been demonstrated to strongly affect the nanoparticle size distributions and microstructure of laser-modified surfaces, the physical mechanisms of laser surface modification and ablation in liquids still remain elusive. This research will address the challenge of multi-scale computational modeling of laser ablation and processing in liquids by developing and applying an advanced computational model which combines a fully atomistic description of laser interactions with metal and semiconductor targets, a coarse-grained representation of liquid environment, and a continuum-level description of heat transfer from the irradiated surface. The simulations will target three interrelated focus areas: (1) study of the fundamental mechanisms of nanoparticle formation in pulsed laser ablation in liquids and evaluation of the dependences of various channels of nanoparticle formation on the irradiation conditions, properties of target material and liquid environment; (2) investigation of the ability of laser ablation in liquids to produce nanoparticles with unusual metastable structures, phase mixtures, and strong chemical supersaturation; and (3) analysis of the processes that control surface morphology and microstructure produced by laser processing in liquids. At the fundamental level, this study will provide unique insights into the material behavior far from equilibrium, under extreme conditions of ultrafast heating, cooling, and mechanical deformation.

por.por_cntn:
The generation of chemically clean and environmentally friendly nanoparticles through pulsed laser ablation in liquids has a number of advantages over conventional chemical synthesis methods and has evolved into a thriving research field attracting laboratory and industrial applications.  Moreover, the interaction of metal surfaces rapidly heated by short pulse laser irradiation with liquid environment can result in a rapid quenching of transient molten surface structures, thus creating conditions for the formation of highly nonequilibrium surface morphology and microstructure.

In the NSF-sponsored research, Professor Zhigilei and his team at the University of Virginia are using advanced computer modeling and theoretical analysis to study the mechanisms and kinetics of structural and phase transformations occurring in pulsed laser ablation in liquids. The advances in the understanding of laser-induced processes make direct impact on the design of new laser ablation setups for controlled generation of nanoparticles and surface structures featuring unusual defect configurations and/or nonequilibrium phase composition.

The research results obtained in this project include the identification of three distinct nanoparticle generation mechanisms operating at different stages of the ablation process and in different parts of the emerging cavitation bubble [Nanoscale 10, 6900, 2018; Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 22, 7077, 2020], explanation of the strong effect the liquid environment has on surface morphology generated in pulsed laser ablation in liquid (collaboration with experimental groups from Lviv Polytechnic National University, Ukraine and University of Crete, Greece) [Nanoscale 12, 7674, 2020], establishment of the origin of the limited elemental mixing in nanoparticles generated in laser ablation of metal bilayers (collaboration with a group from the University of University of Duisburg-Essen, Germany) [J. Phys. Chem. C 125, 2132, 2021], and the prediction of new physical regimes of laser fragmentation of nanoparticles in liquid [J. Phys. Chem. C 125, 13413, 2021; Sci. China: Phys. Mech. Astron. 65, 274206, 2022]. Some of these results are illustrated in the figures included with this report.

The broader impacts of this program are in the implications of the advancement of the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the generation of metastable nanoparticles and surface structures for the development of new laser processing techniques for fabrication of nanoparticles and surfaces morphologies with properties fine-tuned for the needs  of biomedical, optical, photovoltaic, and sensing applications. The impact of the computational results is amplified by collaborations with experimental groups from Germany, Ukraine, Greece, Denmark, and China. Six out of eleven publications reporting the results of this project are co-authored with (informal) experimental collaborators.

On the educational side, the program has provided training and multidisciplinary research experience to graduate students involved in this project. All students supported by this award were trained in parallel programming and used high-performance computing resources at the NSF-supported Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE). Two students served as co-PIs on the XSEDE Research Computing Awards. The students involved in this project received prestigious awards at the university as well as national/international levels. In particular, Dr. Maxim Shugaev, was awarded the 2020 Dieter W. B?uerle Prize for Fundamentals and Applications of Laser-Matter-Interactions. The PI Zhigilei served as a co-director of the 2022 Venice International School on Lasers in Materials Science (SLIMS) and facilitated the participation of eight students from the United States in this School. He also served as a lecturer at graduate summer schools on Surfaces Light Engineering in St. Etienne, France, Ultra-short Pulse Lasers Applications in Material Processing in Vilnius, Lithuania, and Laser Processing Technology in Advanced Manufacturing in Wuhan, China.
